docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Okinawa Way: How The World's Longest-Lived People Achieve Everlasting Health,'' by Dr. Bradley J. Willcox, Dr. D. Craig Willcox, and Dr. Makoto Suzuki, Clarkson Potter/Publishers, $24.95. Envy the Okinawans, the inhabitants of the 161 islands that stretch 600 miles between Japan and Taiwan. When Okinawans die, it is at the average age of 86 for women, and over 75 for men, making them the longest-lived people in the world.

headline.main: Exploring Okinawans' Recipes for Longer Lives

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews The Okinawa Way: How The World's Longest-Lived People Achieve Everlasting Health, by Dr Bradley J Willcox, Dr D Craig Willcox and Dr Makoto Suzuki; illus (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In May 1987, Dan Shapiro, then a 20-year-old junior at Vassar College, discovered he had Hodgkin's disease. After seven months of treatment with four chemotherapy drugs and radiation, he seemed healthy again. In 1988, in his first year of graduate school in clinical psychology, he counseled a young girl named Jodi who was not doing well after a bone marrow transplant for the same cancer and who soon died. Six months later, he learned that his own cancer had returned and that his only hope was a bone marrow transplant. His survival chances were 40 percent. Sixteen months after the transplant, in July 1991, he had a second relapse, and few options remained.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH: Dan Shapiro; A Doctor's Story of Hope, Humor and Deadly Cancer

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Dan Shapiro, clinical psychologist and former cancer patient in Tucson, Ariz, who applies what he has learned to help patients get what they need from doctors, and to help doctors practice more humane and integrated form of medicine; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Susie Hott demanded to see her dying son, Theresa Meyers, a nurse on duty at Parkland Health and Hospital System in Dallas, could not bear to refuse. She persuaded the doctor in charge to let Ms. Hott observe the medical team's frantic resuscitation efforts, even though her presence violated standard hospital procedure. Ms. Hott's 14-year-old son, Donnie, had fallen from a tree and severely damaged his liver. As the Parkland staff futilely tried to save him, his mother urged the boy, an avid wrestler, to ''get up off the mat.'' His father, also there, apologized for a fight they had the day before.

headline.main: A Debate Over Loved Ones in the E.R.

docs.abstract: Debate is going on in medical circles over whether family members and loved ones should be permitted in emergency room to observe efforts to save a person's life, an experience that has potential to be traumatizing; photos (L)
docs.snippet: When Susie Hott demanded to see her dying son, Theresa Meyers, a nurse on duty at Parkland Health and Hospital System in Dallas, could not bear to refuse. She persuaded the doctor in charge to let Ms. Hott observe the medical team's frantic...

docs.lead_paragraph: A colleague recounting the circumstances of his father's recent death ultimately thanked the family doctor who had failed to diagnose the man's cancer. The doctor attended the funeral/ memorial service and, after expressing his profound regrets about the death, told the family that he'd been very distraught about the missed diagnosis and had gone back over the original X-rays to see what he'd missed. But, he said, even after knowing his patient had cancer, he still could not detect it on the film.

headline.main: After a Death, Doctors Can Offer Families Healing Help

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on healing help that doctors can offer after a death in the family; drawing (M)
